title: Handoff Breakdown: Chairside → Front Desk
summary: Doctor resolves a patient-plan mismatch instantly, but the handoff structure remains broken.

scene.setting: Busy WA office. Patient expects same-day filling, but insurance coverage needs verification first.

beats.narration: Doctor explains treatment chairside. Assistant will chart and hand off to front desk.

dialogue.speaker: doc
dialogue.line: #30 MOD composite. If insurance covers it today, do it. Otherwise we schedule.

beats.narration: Front desk tells patient the plan as same-day filling without confirming the insurance condition.

dialogue.speaker: pt
dialogue.line: Wait, I thought we were checking insurance first?

beats.narration: The mismatch lands on the doctor. Everyone looks to you to fix it now.

dialogue.speaker: asst
dialogue.line: I thought you said we're doing it today?

choices.label: Fix it yourself now. Move on fast.

steps.step: After the patient is settled, take 7–10 minutes with assistant + front desk.
Ask two questions to locate the handoff break.
Declare one structural rule for future chairside handoffs.

leader_lines: Hey—quick 5 minutes. Where did the handoff break?
When I say something chairside, what part is confusing or easy to mis-hear?
questions: What exact words did you hear from me?
At what step should we confirm before telling the patient?
scripts.closing_line: From now on: before sending to front, repeat back the plan in ONE sentence.

choices.label: Clarify with the patient, then create a confirmation step with the team.

steps.step: Clarify the plan with patient in one sentence (insurance condition included).
Do a 7-minute team huddle: assistant repeats back, front repeats back.
Write the one-sentence handoff rule in the note template.

leader_lines: Let me clarify: we do it today IF coverage is confirmed—otherwise we schedule.
Okay team—repeat back the plan in one sentence before we tell the patient.
questions: Assistant—what's the one-sentence plan you're sending?
Front—what's the one sentence you'll tell the patient?

choices.label: Delegate ownership: assistant owns chart wording, front owns patient wording, you only verify.

steps.step: Assign ownership explicitly (assistant chart line / front patient line).
Set one checkpoint: they must repeat back before speaking to patient.
End-of-day 2-minute check: did we use the repeat-back today?

leader_lines: Assistant owns the chart line. Front owns the patient line.
Before we tell the patient—repeat it back to me in one sentence.
scripts.closing_line: Tomorrow we'll do the same—repeat-back is the rule.

choices.label: Do nothing now; let the team figure it out.

steps.step: Within 24 hours, do a 5-minute reset: name the issue without blame.
Set the one-sentence repeat-back rule anyway.

leader_lines: No blame—today the handoff broke. We fix the system.
questions: What's the one-sentence plan we'll repeat back?

system_prompts.nudge: Today speed won. But the handoff structure didn't change.
system_prompts.mirror_call: You fixed it fast—did the team learn the structure, or did you absorb the cost again?

outcomes.message: Two weeks later, the same insurance condition mismatch shows up again. People still look to you to rescue it instantly.
reflection_questions: What would have changed if repeat-back became the default?
Did speed protect the team—or train dependence?

outcomes.message: Two weeks later, the front desk repeats the plan back before speaking. The patient hears the insurance condition clearly and tension stays low.
reflection_questions: Which single sentence made the difference?
What part of your leadership became lighter?

tsp.weekly_pulse_prompt: This week felt more stable than last week. (1-5)
